title: Potentially remove partial() and the concept of layouts etc
body:
Jade now supports [template inheritance](https://gist.github.com/1205026) similar to Django, which are not necessarily "better" than partial() etc, in some ways at least, however it would clean up Express greatly to ditch this logic. If there's a time to do it, it's in 3.0 :) 

ejs and others depending on partial() and friends will need something as well

title: cookie is uri encoded?
body:
Not sure if this is an error in my app, express, or node, but it appears that cookies are being uri-encoded. I think that the only character that needs to be encoded - if any - is `;`.

For now, I'm just wrapping cookie reading with decodeURIComponent. (If you want to read a cookie in node code, you probably don't need that, but if you want to read it clientside, you do, for now.)

```
var array = [one, two, three]
app.get(url, array)
```

Doesn't work, where as

```
var array = [one, two]
app.get(url, array, three)
```

Does work. 

Can we support the former?

title: Difficulty wrapping brain around Express
body:
So, I’ve been doing local web development for ages using [MAMP](http://www.mamp.info).  And it works just fine.  

The thing is, when I started with MAMP ages ago, PHP + MySQL were hot shit.  And Apache was the infallible god of all web servers.

…But not so much any more.  

So, I’ve been keeping my eyes open for an alternative to do local web development in.  

It needs to be human-friendly to set up, use, configure, and develop sites with.  And most importantly, I want to thoroughly understand how to migrate any tweaks I made to Apache to the new web server.

---

It’s only been a few months since I heard about Node, npm, Connect, and Express.  I’ve never been a fan of Javascript (please don’t hate me! ☺), but it has always been used to do amazing things, so I use it when it can get me something in return that is un-gettable (or un-gettable for a reasonable effort).  

Express looks pretty impressive.  It’s one of those pieces of software that makes me forget my negative reactions to Javascript and drool over the possibilities going through my mind as I read through the example code snippets on the Express homepage.

One of the things that impressed me the most about Express was how its configuration is set up.  While reading through those blocks of code examples on the Express website, it looks so very simple.  My memory flashes back to an Apache configuration file and I want to vomit because the difference is just so _drastic_!  

---

But it turns out, that thing that looks so attractive to me is exactly what confuses me the most about Express.  I’m _too set in my ways_ with Apache.  When I sit down to write some basic code for Express, I’m constantly interrupted by something like, “Okay, I know what I want to tell the server to do next…but I have absolutely no idea how to do it!”

And flipping back and forth between the Express documentation and my editor helped a bit at first.  Then it became a lot of noise against the signal that was what I sat down to code.  And finally, I started to encounter questions to which I could find no answer on Express’ website.  

---

So after all that… 

**First** , I’d like to request a new page for the Express documentation: 

**Migrating from Apache**. with examples of the most common stuff done in Apache configuration files, and how you’d code the same thing in Express.

**Second,** I would like to ask about the following specifics that I want to set up Express to do:
- XML Includes
- Template engine using XSL / XQuery 
- Tell Express that files with extension `.blah` should be processed by program `blah` before being served (like telling Apache that `*.php` files should be processed with PHP)

---

Yeah, I’m an XML junkie at heart.  I know, I know…it’s out of fashion, JSON is in, and by now you probably think I’m a misguided dinosaur or something.  And that’s okay.  ☺  (I’m not blind to XML’s flaws, I just have a deep-seated appreciation for its strengths.)

But even if you mock my love for XML, the underlying issue here is wrapping my brain around this radically different way of setting up a web server.  This is just so freakin’ alien.  Beautiful, wonderful, and elegant—but _alien_.  

Do I have hope?

title: hierarchical route definitions
body:
I refuse to do this until I'm happy with _how_ you define such a thing, but it would be useful for cutting down boilerplate code and everything we have now could be built on top of this, so I'm going to start brainstorming here :).

While what we have right now is not really an issue, one might typically do something like the following:

``` js
app.all('/admin/*', ensure.loggedIn, ensure.role('admin'), accessLogger);
app.get('/admin', admin.show);
app.get('/admin/stats', stats.load, stats.json);
```

Internally this would be easier to manage with the following representation, but useful as a public API as well.  

``` js
app
  .get('/admin')
  .use(ensure.loggedIn)
  .use(ensure.role('admin'))
  .use(accessLogger)
  .end(admin.show)
  .get('/stats')
    .use(stats.load)
    .end(stats.json)
  .get('/users')
    .use(users.load)
    .end(users.show)
    .get('/:id')
      .use(user.get)
      .end(user.show);
```

I can see this getting out of hand quite quickly though, and if users dont abstract out the callbacks to some other file and try to define them inline along with `.get()` / `.use()` etc it _will_ look like hell. Another problem is that for an API like above, without having an explicit zero-arg `.end()` like jQuery we need an explicit end-point callback, though we can treat it as middleware internally. This method might look like this:

``` js
   .end = function(fn){
     this.use(fn);
     return this.pop();
   }
```

with this change the param callbacks could easily be normalized as well:

``` js
app.param(':uid', loadUser);
app.get('/user/:uid', callback);
```

internal representation:

``` js
app
  .get('/user/:uid')
  .use(loadUser)
  .end(callback)
```

and:

``` js
app.param(':uid', user.load);
app.param(':pid', post.load);
app.get('/user/:uid', user.show);
app.get('/user/:uid/post/:pid', post.show);
app.del('/user/:uid/post/:pid', post.destroy);
```

would be equivalent to:

``` js
app
  .get('/user/:uid')
  .use(user.load)
  .end(user.show)
  .get('/post/:pid')
    .use(post.load)
    .end(post.show)
    .del()
      .end(post.destroy);
```

we could go further and take `.del(callback)` etc to be equivalent to `.del().end(callback)`.

title: (Windows) res.redirect('/x') sends browser to '\x'
body:
Node 0.5.4 on Windows XP (blech).
Express 2.4.3

Using res.redirect('/somepath') on Windows results in a redirect that uses a backslash instead of a forward slash:

``` text
HTTP/1.1 302 Moved Temporarily
X-Powered-By: Express
Content-Type: text/html
Location: http://127.0.0.1\somepath
```

Safari 5 and Firefox 5 can't handle URLs with a backslash like that. Chrome 13 and IE8 work ok--they seem to auto-correct the path.

Again, this problem only happens when you're running Node on Windows.

title: make getting an array of _all_ routes easy
Session cookies set multiple times
body:
When renewing a session cookie, the SetCookie header will contain both the old value and the new value. When calling res.clearCookie, the SetCookie header will contain one empty cookie and one with the new value.

```
 Set-Cookie: session=; path=/; expires=Thu, 01 Jan 1970 00:00:00 GMT, session=04aa42004e9e4efcd59f2f1c8362e925; path=/; expires=Fri, 12 Aug 2011 22:05:56 GMT
```

I experienced some confusing results when not using clearCookie - subsequent requests sometimes used the old cookie, sometimes the new. This happens with both the default session storage implementation and my own (couchDB).

Why doesn't express just overwrite the "old" cookie instead of appending a new one? Or am I getting something wrong here? I mean, if I happened to be a browser that should parse this stuff, I would be really confused about this.

title: Jade Escaping Script
body:
I looked through the issues for a while, and [this](https://github.com/visionmedia/jade/issues/75) appeared to talk about the same issue.  This may be closed again, but figured it didn't hurt to bring it back up. 

Anyways when working with script blocks jade appears to ignore escaping `/`.  For example:

```
script
  window.jQuery || document.write('<script src="javascripts/libs/jquery-1.6.1.min.js"><\/script>')
```

It compiles down to

```
<script>window.jQuery || document.write('<script src="javascripts/libs/jquery-1.6.1.min.js"></script>')</script>
```

This closes the `</script>` tag early making invalid Javascript and displaying in this case `')`

Considering that above is common boilerplate code, It would be nice to reconsider looking at this issue, especially because it could potentially mess up copy and paste JavaScript code.

Obviously you could potentially escape twice but hey that is slightly ugly.

```
script
  window.jQuery || document.write('<script src="javascripts/libs/jquery-1.6.1.min.js"><\\/script>')
```

title: express.vhost() + socket.io
body:
Using express.vhost on a socket.io app leads to errors : hang up, falling back to xhr-polling, disconnections,  ...

```
var express = require('express')
  , app = express.createServer()
  , server = express.createServer()
app.get('/', function (req, res) {
    res.send('\
<html>\
<body>\
    <script src="/socket.io/socket.io.js"></script>\
    <script>io.connect("http://localhost")</script>\
</body>\
</html>')
})
io = require('socket.io').listen(app)
server.use(express.vhost('localhost', app));
server.listen(80)
```

node v0.4.10, express 2.4.4, socket.io 0.7.7

title: replace dynamic helpers/locals with middleware-like api
body: not sure what to call it yet. we could do basically the same thing with regular middleware and `res.locals`, though ideally these would all run in parallel and once they all `next()` the template would render. _so_ that's all good, but it could be potentially awkward / wasteful to actually use middleware for this, since this logic should be performed before the render itself and no earlier. This functionality could be built into the view system but the API would look identical to middleware

title: Error in unix_dgram bind of /tmp/cluster.2836.server.sock
body:
Hi, 

I'm getting the following error when trying to run on a linux machine. The code works fine on my mac. Any ideas as to what may be causing the socket to not be bound?

Error in unix_dgram bind of /tmp/cluster.5911.server.sock
Error: stream not writable
    at [object Object].write (fs.js:1162:24)
    at EventEmitter.log (/usr/local/zend/apache2/htdocs/Twepto.CrowdCreator/source/node_modules/log/lib/log.js:152:19)
    at EventEmitter.info (/usr/local/zend/apache2/htdocs/Twepto.CrowdCreator/source/node_modules/log/lib/log.js:235:10)
    at Master.<anonymous> (/usr/local/zend/apache2/htdocs/Twepto.CrowdCreator/source/node_modules/cluster/lib/plugins/logger.js:55:11)
    at Master.emit (events.js:86:20)
    at Socket.<anonymous> (/usr/local/zend/apache2/htdocs/Twepto.CrowdCreator/source/node_modules/cluster/lib/master.js:350:10)
    at Socket.emit (events.js:62:17)
    at dgram.js:127:16

The file /tmp/cluster.5911.server.sock is successfully being created. 

Here's my code: 

cluster('app.js')
      .set('workers', 1)
      .set('socket path', '/tmp')
      .use(cluster.pidfiles('shared/pids'))
      .use(cluster.logger('shared/logs'))
      .use(cluster.stats({ connections: true, requests: true }))
      .use(cluster.repl(8888, '127.0.0.1'))
      .use(cluster.debug())
      .listen(3000);

I've tried using a default ./ socket path and /var/run as well. 

Thanks,

Matt

title: Route middleware context drama
body:
I **love** the route-specific middleware idea. However, it's really difficult to use when you're trying to be class-y, since the "this" context varies wildly depending on how you use it.

If you use it in the app.get line, which is my preferred method, you get some sort of global context thing returned with this. If you do it as part of the route body, you get the more localized (and preferred) scope.

Test case:
main file: https://gist.github.com/1108725
bugmodel.js file:  https://gist.github.com/1108728

Ideally, I'd prefer "this" in the route middleware style, to give you the same context you'd get when you use it inline w/ the route.

My workaround, for now, is to build functions into the main file, which give me the more localized context without modifying my classes.

Also, should note, I'm on Express 2.4.2 from NPM.

I'm not sure if this is less specific or express.

title: How to register underscore template as view engine?
bodyParsing and arrays
body:
It's not clear from the docs/examples how to parse more hierarchical object structures from a POST request.

```
<input type="text" name="item[name]">
<input type="text" name="item[price]">
```

is great but what if you need:

```
<input type="text" name="item[0][name]">
<input type="text" name="item[0][price]">
<input type="text" name="item[1][name]">
<input type="text" name="item[1][price]">
```

How is this meant to be handled? Shouldn't the body parser be smart enough to create the proper structure from this?

title: Fix * routing
body: Currently, when using a wildcard route, you're required to have something in the URL for the wildcard to match against.  Setting up a route as /admin\* should match /admin just as well as /admin/XXXX.  This pull request fixes that, and includes a test.

title: Simple misspelling fix.
body: Fixing the misspelling of "manor" with "manner" in the 4 places it occurs. First time using github!

title: Extend core protos per request
body: I need to benchmark this, but if we utilize **proto** per-request to extend the request/response protos we can have multiple varying version of express co-exist in the same process

title: Registered template engines should be app-level caches
body: currently it's in part of the view system but this should be specific to the app

title: res.sendfile() changes
body: currently res.sendfile() is much like connect.static() in that it supports index.html, supports ../ etc, not really necessary, if someone wants this behaviour you can just use the middleware, even if it's within a route.

title: Only send implied OPTIONS response when allowed methods are found.
body:
I suggest changing in express/lib/router/index.js, so that when no methods are found, then router should just pass on, so myApi could answer with the myApi.options() which it has defined. Currently app.router replies with an empty 'Allow' request header, even if some methods are accepted for the route.

See reference discussion here: https://groups.google.com/forum/#!msg/express-js/0oNFpyH51_k/VUTLGnA2UYQJ

title: In 2.x, empty `request.send` triggers node http warning
body:
As of Node 0.4.10, an error is printed when `response.write()` or `response.end()` is called with a body for responses where HTTP forbids it.

However, in express (2.4.3), `response.send()` with no parameters fills the body with `204`, triggering that error.

title: Simple modification in generated template hangs expresso test
Doc change to gh-pages branch tied to Pull #767
body:
Doc change to gh-pages branch tied to [Pull #767](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/pull/767)
- Updated gh-pages branch with doc change.

title: Modification + Merge of Pulls #764 + #755
body: This pull puts together pulls [#764](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/pull/764) from @adrienbrault, [#755](https://github.com/visionmedia/express/pull/755) from @gdpotter and additional modifications missing from those pulls (such as  updating broken example code, and generating the documentation).

title: Make reusable apps possible
body:
It would be great, to have the ability to have apps packed in npm-modules so it would be possible to plug in apps simply by installing them via nmp

Directory structure could be as follows:

root
+-- node_modules
|     +-- express
|     +-- express-blog
|     |       +-- views
|     |       |     +-- express-blog
|     |       |            +-- post.jade
|     |       |            +-- edit.jade
|     |      +-- index.js
|     +-- express-foo
|             +-- views
|             |     +-- express-foo
|             |            +-- bar.jade
|             |            +-- foo.jade
|            +-- index.js
+-- public
+-- views
|      +-- express-foo
|      |      +-- bar.jade
|      +-- index.jade
|      +-- layout.jade
+-- app.js
+-- package.json

As you can see, every module might bring his own templates which can be overwritten in global context.

title: Convenience app.alias() method
body:
Having redirects becomes a natural part of any app as it grows over time and the URLs need to change. It's also nice to have redirects for URLs you expect your users might hit (e.g. /help -> /faq until you build a proper help section =D).

We thus found it really useful to add a simple `app.alias()` method both to declare redirects easily and to list them directly alongside our routes. Here's our simple implementation:

``` coffee-script
# convenience alias method for quick and simple redirects
# TODO support passing through parameters, e.g. ':id' etc.
app.alias = (from, to, status=301) ->
    @get from, (req, res, _) ->
        res.redirect to, status
```

And here's example usage:

``` coffee-script
app.alias '/aseem', '/aseemk'
app.alias '/daniel', '/gasi'
app.alias '/help', '/faq'
app.alias '/users', '/people'
```

What do you think of adding a simple `app.alias()` convenience redirect wrapper like this to core? As a next step then, it would be great for it to pass parameters through too, e.g. `/users/:id` -> `/people/:id`.

Thanks for the consideration. =)

/cc @gasi

title: New site
body:
features I'd like:
- new docs
- better doc organization (guide, reference, use-cases)
- "branding" aka express logo etc, and lighter design
- easier addition of apps instead of the browser screenshots right now
- multiple languages

title: Update docs for related changes
body: before an alpha

title: Decouple Rendering from Response
body:
I'm trying to devise a clean way to extend the Express  rendering system.  I might be mistaken, but it doesn't look like there is any way to take advantage of Express logic for rendering views/layouts without sending the result to the response? I know its possible to manually do this myself, but I'd much rather call/reuse code provided by Express.

Just for a bit of context, I'd like this as  I'm building an add-on that would render any view as a PDF or PNG, rather than HTML.  So ideally, I'd like to take the same args as res.render, generate the HTML, convert it to PDF, then write it to the response.

title: How to have the router middleware before and after the static middleware?
body:
Currently I have the order of my middlewares like so:
- static
- methodOverride
- bodyParser
- router

That works fine, but given my last route is:

``` coffeescript
# WWW Redirect
docpadServer.get '*', (req, res, next) ->
    # Prepare
    requestInfo = {url: req.headers.host+req.url, ip: req.connection.remoteAddress, status: res.statusCode}

    # Handle
    if req.headers.host in ['www.balupton.com','lupton.cc','www.lupton.cc','balupton.no.de']
        res.redirect 'http://balupton.com'+req.url, 301
    else
        console.log 'not found:', requestInfo
        res.send(404) # Not Found
```

And say I access http://www.balupton.com/ it will hit the static router then discontinue the loop, so it will not reach that route and get redirects to http://balupton.com/

Moving the static middleware last will cause 404s to just hang forever keeping the connection open and eventually the server will run out of resources and crash.

The only solutions I see are either:
- Be able to have the router middleware before and after the static middleware
- Have the static middleware second last, and have a new middleware which always just sends `res.send(404);` to go last.

Thoughts?

title: Remove res.local(), and make res.locals() a middleware definition
body:
this means:

```
 res.local(key, val);
 res.locals(obj);
 res.locals() // => obj
```

would become:

```
res.locals.key = val
res.locals(obj)
res.locals
```

refactor app level as well

title: Remove app.dynamicLocals
body: just use middleware, less confusing, less api

title: Fixed app.locals for options used by _render
body: I moved the code that merges app._locals to into options so that it could actually be used by options used by _render() like options.layout.  Without this change, setting the layout in app.local() doesn't work.

title: app.locals and app.dynamicLocals doesn't do anything
body: I just pulled the latest version of express (I wanted to start moving my code from "helper" to "local" now) and I seem to have hit a problem.  When I define something in app.locals or app.dynamicLocals, it doesn't make it to the view.  I looked at view.js, in the _render function and you define variables (locals and dynamic) at lines 337 and 338, but then you never reference them again.

title: Can't store functions on the session.
body: Maybe more of a connect issue, but is it possible to store functions in a session?  One of the things in my session holds a bunch of user permissions, and I wanted to be able to have a isPermitted() function.  That way, I just have to call, req.session.isPermitted(SOMETHING).

title: NODE_ENV should be called EXPRESS_ENV (or something)
body:
As a newbie, I expected NODE_ENV to be something of node.js itself. Looking through the code and docs it seems to be specifically used by express. I'd like the name to reflect that, because the current name is confusing.

Googl'ing around I found it it was previously called EXPRESS_ENV and was renamed to have a unified name between web frameworks. I understand the need to have some unification at this front, but I'd argue it's too soon (in terms of maturity of node.js) and just making shit up is not a good way to improve the current situation.

title: Check if a response has been sent?
body:
Is there any way to test if a response has been sent already?

For context, I'm finding that some non-existing url queries end up just hanging, so I created

``` coffeescript
# Timeout Handling
((req,res) ->
    setTimeout(
        ->
            # Prepare
            requestInfo = {url: req.headers.host+req.url, ip: req.connection.remoteAddress, status: res.statusCode}

            # Attempt Timeout
            try
                res.send(408) # Request Timeout
                console.log 'request timeout:', requestInfo
                #res.end() # End Response
                #console.log 'end response:', requestInfo
            catch err
                # Chances are the request sent fine
                false
        30*1000
    )                       
)(req,res)
```

but even with the catch it restarts the entire process
